title: Shreejikrupa Project Ltd vs State Of Chhattisgarh on 12 April, 2012
doc:
Shreejikrupa Project Ltd vs State Of Chhattisgarh on 12 April, 2012

       

  

  

 
 
   HIGH COURT OF CHATTISGARH AT BILASPUR          

  Arbitration Application No 38 of 2011


  Shreejikrupa  Project  Ltd
                               ...Petitioners

          Versus


  1  State  of  Chhattisgarh

   2  The Executive Engineer PWD 
                                  ...Respondents

! Mr A K Mishra counsel for the applicant ^ Dr G D Vaswani G A for the non applicants CORAM: Honble Mr N K Agarwal J Dated: 12/04/2012 : Judgement ORAL ORDER (12.04.2012) APPLICATION UNDER SECTION 11 (6) OF THE ARBITRATION AND CONCILIATION ACT, 1996

1. The question falls for consideration of this Court is whether in view of provisions contained in M.P./C.G. Madhyastham Adhikaran Adhiniyam, 1983 (for short 'the Adhiniyam of 1983), the instant application filed under Section 11 (6) of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (henceforth `the Act of 1996') for appointment of sole Arbitrator is maintainable?

2. The applicant-firm entered into a works contract on 6.9.2006 with the respondents for the work of construction of New Engineering College building at Sejbahar, Raipur (C.G.). The agreement entered into between the parties contains an arbitration clause, i.e., clause - 28, which reads as under:

ARBITRATION CLAUSE:
"Clause 28: Except as otherwise provided in this contract all question and dispute relating to the meaning of the specification, designs, drawings and instruction herein before mentioned as to thing whatsoever in any way arising out of or relating to the contract designs, drawings specification, estimte, concerning the works, or the execution or failure to execute the same, whether arising during the progress of the work, or after the abandonment thereof shall be referred to the Superintending Engineer for his decision, within a period of 30 (thirty) days of such an occurrence(s). There upon the Superintending Engineer shall give his written instructions and/or decisions, after hearing the contractor and Executive Engineer within a period of 15 (fifteen) days of such request. This period can be extended by mutual consent of parties.
Upon receipt of written instructions or decisions, of Superintending Engineer the parties shall promptly proceed without delay to comply such instructions or decisions. If the Superintending Engineer fails to give his instruction or decisions in writing within a period of 15 (fifteen) days or mutually agreed time after being requested and/or, if the party(es) is/are aggrieved against the decision of the Superintending Engineer, the aggrieved party may within 30 days prefer an appeal to the Chief Engineer, who shall afford an opportunity to the parties of being heard and to offer evidence in support of his appeal. The Chief Engineer will give his decision within 30 (thirty) days, or such, mutually agreed period.
If any party is not satisfied with the decision of the Chief Engineer he can file a petition for resolving the dispute through arbitration in the arbitration tribunal. A reference to Arbitration Tribunal shall be no ground for not continuing the work on the part of the Contractor. Payment as per original terms and condition of the agreement shall be continued by the Executive Engineer in accordance with clauses 8 above."

3. The dispute and differences arose between the parties with regard to payment of Rs.56,26,90,967.00 and other damages. The applicant-firm vide letter dated 16.12.2010 by invoking arbitration clause 28 requested respondents' Superintending Engineer to enter upon the reference and decide their matter. The Superintending Engineer did not respond timely, so the petitioner has filed an appeal to the Chief Engineer vide letter dated 27.01.2011. The Chief Engineer also did not respond within time specified under clause 28 of the agreement. Hence, vide letter dated 28.02.2011 (Annexure A/7), the applicant-firm requested the non-applicants to constitute Arbitration Tribunal in terms of arbitration clause. The non-applicants did not respond to the above request also. Hence, this application for appointment of arbitrator under Section 11 (6) of the Act of 1996.

4. Shri A.K.Mishra, learned counsel appearing for the applicant, would submit: the judgment of Supreme Court passed in Civil Appeal 3747/2005, parties being Va Tech Escher Wyass Flovel Ltd. v. M.P.S.E.B and another1, squarely applies in the facts and circumstances of the case, inasmuch as, the agreement in the instant case contains an arbitration clause, and therefore, this application filed under Section 11 (6) of the Act of 1996 is maintainable.

5. Per contra, Shri G.D.Vaswani, learned Government Advocate appearing for the non-applicants/State, would submit: admittedly, the nature of the dispute is such, which falls within the definition of "works contract" under Section 2 (i) of the Adhiniyam of 1983 and one of the contracted parties to the agreement is State of Chhattisgarh, therefore, irrespective of arbitration clause contained in the agreement, the dispute will have to be referred to the Arbitration Tribunal in terms of Section 7 of the Adhiniyam 1983. For this, he placed reliance upon the judgment of the Supreme Court in the case of Madhya Pradesh Rural Road Development Authority and another v. L.G.Chaudhary Engineers and contractors2.

6. I have heard counsel for the parties and perused the material available on record.

7. Admittedly, in the instant case, the nature of the dispute falls within the definition of "works contract"

under Section 2 (i) of the Adhiniyam 1983 and one of the contracted parties to the agreement is State of Chhattisgarh. It is also an admitted fact that the dispute is in relation to the execution of works contract and the contract is well in existence meaning thereby the contract itself has neither been terminated, cancelled nor repudiated by the non-applicants.

8. In Va Tech Escher Wyass Flovel Ltd. v. M.P.S.E.B and another (supra), the Hon'ble Supreme Court, after referring to both the Adhiniyam 1983 and the Act of 1996, held that the Adhiniyam 1983 applies only where there is no arbitration clause and the Adhiniyam 1983 stands impliedly repealed by the Act of 1996 where there is an arbitration clause.

9. The exact reasoning recorded by the Hon'ble Supreme Court in Va Tech Escher Wyass Flovel Ltd. v. M.P.S.E.B and another (supra) is as follows:

"3. ... In our opinion, the 1983 Act and the 1996 Act can be harmonised by holding that the 1983 Act only applies where there is no arbitration clause but it stands impliedly repealed by the 1996 Act where there is an arbitration clause. We hold accordingly. Hence, the impugned judgment cannot be sustained and we hold that the application under Section 9 of the 1996 Act maintainable"

10. In another case, the Hon'ble Apex Court presided over by the same learned Judge who gave Va Tech Escher Wyass Flovel Ltd. v. M.P.S.E.B and another (supra) ruling passed the following order:

"This petition has been filed against the judgment and order dated 11.3.2011 passed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Gwalior Bench in Ravi Kant Bansal v. General Manager"

11. Recently, the two Judge Bench of Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Madhya Pradesh Rural Road Development Authority and another v. L.G.Chaudhary Engineers and contractors (supra) has considered the question whether the provisions of Adhiniyam 1983, which statutorily provide for the parties to the works contract to refer all disputes to Arbitration Tribunal constituted under Section 7 of the Adhiniyam 1983 will continue to operate in view of the provisions of the Act of 1996, which is a central Act subsequently enacted.

12. In the opinion of Hon'ble Shri Justice A.K.Ganguly:

"39. The M.P. Act of 1983 was made when the previous Arbitration Act of 1940 was in the field. That Act of 1940 was a Central law. Both the Acts operated in view of Section 46 of the 1940 Act. The M.P.Act, 1983 was reserved for the assent of the President and admittedly received the same on 17-10-1983 which was published in the Madhya Pradesh Gazette Extraordinary dated 12-10- 1983. Therefore, the requirement of article 354(2) of the Constitution was satisfied. Thus, the M.P. Act of 1983 prevails in the State of Madhya Pradesh. Thereafter, the AC Act, 1996 was enacted by Parliament repealing the earlier laws of arbitration of 1940. It has also been noted that the AC Act, 1996 saves the provisions of the M.P. Act, 1983 under Sections 2(4) and 2 (5) thereof. Therefore, there cannot be any repugnancy. (See the judgment of this Court in T.Barai v. Henry Ah Hoe, (1983), 1 SCC 177)
40. In this connection the observations made by the Constitution Bench of this Court in M. Karunanidhi v. Union of India, (1979) 3 SCC 431 are very pertinent and the following observations are excerpted: (SCC p.450, para 37) "37. .... It is, therefore, clear that in view of this clear intention of the legislature there can be no room for any argument that the State Act was in any way repugnant to the Central Acts. We have already pointed out from the decisions of the Federal Court and this Court that one of the important tests to find out as to whether or not there is repugnancy is to ascertain the intention of the legislature regarding the fact that the dominant legislature allowed the subordinate legislature to operate in the same field pari passu the State Act."

41. It is clear from the aforesaid observations that in the instant case the latter Act made by Parliament i.e. the AC Act, 1996 clearly showed an intention to the effect that the State law of arbitration i.e. the M.P.Act should operate in the State of Madhya Pradesh in respect of certain specified types of arbitrations which are under the M.P.Act, 1983. This is clear from Sections 2 (4) and 2 (5) of the AC Act, 1996. Therefore, there is no substance in the argument of repugnancy and is accordingly rejected.

42. Therefore, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court which is based on the reasoning of Va Tech is set aside. This Court holds that the decision in Va Tech has been rendered per incuriam. In that view of the matter the arbitration proceeding may proceed under the M.P. Act of 1983 and not under the AC Act, 1996."

13. However, Hon'ble Justice Gyan Sudha Misra, while concurring and endorsing the reasonings assigned in the judgment of Hon'ble Shri Justice A.K.Ganguly has delivered partly disagreeing opinion. According to Hon'ble Justice Gyan Sudha Misra, the question as to whether the dispute would be referred to the M.P.Arbitration Tribunal in terms of Section 7 of the Adhiniyam 1983 or to an independent arbitrator under the Act of 1996 will depend upon the fact whether the works contract is existing between the parties or not out of which the dispute has arisen. In case, the works contract itself has been repudiated/cancelled, then in view of its non-existence, Section 7 of the M.P.Act pertaining to reference of dispute to the Tribunal would not come into play at all by virtue of the fact that the dispute relating to execution of works contract alone can be referred to the Tribunal in view of the specific nature of works contract enumerated within the definition of works contract under the Act of 1983. However, when the works contract itself becomes non-existence as a consequence of its cancellation, the matter will have to be referred to an independent arbitrator under the Act of 1996 and not to the M.P.State Arbitration Tribunal.

14. Thus, in view of some divergence of the view expressed in the two judgments delivered by both the Hon'ble Judges, the matter was placed by their Lordships to the Hon'ble the Chief Justice of India for constituting a larger Bench to resolve the divergence.

15. A careful reading of the judgment of Supreme Court in the case referred herein above would reveal: in the opinion of both the Hon'ble Judges, if there is a dispute in relation to execution of works contract within the meaning of Section 2 (i) of the Adhiniyam 1983, then irrespective of fact whether the agreement contains an arbitration clause or not, the dispute is required to be referred to the M.P./C.G. Arbitration Tribunal for adjudication. Their Lordships have differed in their opinion in a case when the works contract itself has been terminated/cancelled or repudiated. Therefore, the above ratio of law laid down by the Supreme Court squarely applies in cases where the dispute is in relation to execution of a works contract and the same is neither terminated nor cancelled or repudiated.

16. Coming to the facts of the present case, admittedly, the contract is a works contract within the meaning of Section 2 (i) of the Adhiniyam 1983. The dispute is in relation to execution of a works contract and the contract is well in existence, inasmuch as, the dispute is not in relation to termination/cancellation or repudiation of the contract. Therefore, the ratio of law laid down by the Supreme Court in the case referred herein above squarely applies in the facts and circumstances of the present case and I am of the opinion, the remedy of the applicant-firm is to refer the matter for adjudication to the C.G. Madhyastham Tribunal constituted under the Adhiniyam 1983 and this application filed under Section 11 (6) of the Act of 1996 is not maintainable.

17. In view of above, the application is dismissed. However, the applicant-firm is at liberty to move an application before the Chhattisgarh Madhyastham Tribunal constituted under the Adhiniyam 1983.

Judge
